Description: A terracotta grotesque head of a man with a thick neck, perhaps once inserted into a body, but made separately. The head is bald and the cheeks are puffed out, the eyes, mouth and ears are applied pellets of clay marked accordingly, and the nostrils and eyebrows are incised. Solid and hand-modelled. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt.
Curator's comments: See Favard-Meeks, in Brissaud and Zivie-Coche Tanis 1987-1997 (1998) p.134.

Terracotta IV Donated: Egypt Exploration Fund. Excavated in House 44 at Tanis. For this house, see registration no. 1885,1101.257. Petrie (1885: 47) dates House 44 to the Ptolemaic period or later and believed it was destroyed in the latter part of the second century AD. Ptolemaic, third or second century BC, but perhaps of the Egyptian Late Period. Comparandum: Not unlike: Petrie 1909: pl. xliii:68, from Memphis. Bibliog: Petrie 1885: 50; Favard-Meeks 1998: 134.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3589)
